abstract.p: James R Maxeiner letter on August 27 article doubts that discrimination plays part in difficulties Mormon and Jewish congregations face in obtaining zoning variances in Westchester County, NY (S)

block.p: The article ''God, Caesar and Zoning'' [Aug. 27] suggests that difficulties in obtaining zoning variances experienced by Mormon and Jewish congregations in Westchester may be a ''polite form of discrimination'' against ''minority religions.'' I doubt it. In Westchester, religious congregations of every denomination are likely to encounter opposition to construction. ''Not in my backyard'' does not discriminate.

The article ''God, Caesar and Zoning'' [Aug. 27] suggests that difficulties in obtaining zoning variances experienced by Mormon and Jewish congregations in Westchester may be a ''polite form of discrimination'' against ''minority religions.'' I doubt it. In Westchester, religious congregations of every denomination are likely to encounter opposition to construction. ''Not in my backyard'' does not discriminate.

The congregation of which I am a member is mainstream Protestant. It has been in our community over 85 years. For decades, it has operated a small school. Yet when we sought to replace the obviously inadequate school structure with a new one, opposition to granting the relatively minor variance required was intense. Construction was delayed for years while the church spent many thousands of dollars on additional professional fees that might better have been spent on educating our children.
